samples.reference: systematic simulations are carried out based on the model of fluidized beds proposed by the present authors [ k.ichiki and h.hayakawa , phys . rev . e * 52 * , 658 ( 1995 ) ] . from our simulation , we confirm that fluidization is a continuous transition . we also confirm the existence of two types of fluidized phases , the channeling phase and the bubbling phase . we find the close relations between the averaged behaviors in fluidized beds and quasi equilibrium states in dense liquids . in fluidized beds , ( i ) the flow rate plays the role of the effective temperature , and ( ii ) the existence of a kind of the fluctuation - dissipation relation is suggested .
samples.generated: we have performed a numerical simulation of a fluidized bed , where energy injection is controlled by the flow of fluid at the bottom . we have observed the transition of fluidization from the fixed phase to the fluidized phase and the existence of two fluidized phases .<n> we have shown that statistical quantities qualitatively change from equilibrium to nonequilibrium . we study numerically the transition from a fluidized state to a nonequilibrium state in a one - dimensional bed of non - interacting particles . in the fluidized phase , we find that the relative motion of particles or the kinetic energy is generated by bubbles which have the difference of the local volume fraction in the system .<n> we also find surprising correspondences in statistical quantities between fluidized beds which is in highly nonequilibrium states and quasi equilibrium systems . <n> it has been a long - standing problem to understand the transition between a fluid state and a quasi equilibrium state in one - dimension ( 1d ) . at the same time<n> , it is an important problem for understanding the transition in 2d systems , because the transition can be either continuous or discontinuous , depending on the nature of the phase transition , such as whether it is a channel , a bubble , or a second - order transition . for the 1d case ,<n> the transition has been studied both experimentally and numerically@xcite . however , for the 2d system , the transition is discontinuous in experiments , while it is continuous in numerical simulations . here<n> we study the transition of a 1d system between two phases , we perform molecular dynamics simulations to study the behavior of a fluidized bed . we find two fluidized phases , _ the channeling phase _ and , where the former changes to the latter as the flow rate @xmath0 increases . above the critical flow rate , particles<n> are fluidized in the channel phase .<n> we find that the flow - rate dependence of the viscosity obeys the arrhenius function , which is consistent with the experimental result in fluidized beds . <n> the phase transition between a fluid and a solid is one of the most fundamental problems in nonequilibrium statistical mechanics . in the simplest case ,<n> it is given by the einstein s theory@xcite . for more complex systems , such as complex fluids , granular materials , or mixtures of them , the transition between two phases<n> is often described by the fluctuation - dissipation relation . however , it is not clear whether this relation can be applied to nonequilibrium systems in general , because the system is in a highly nonequilibrium state and the correlation functions in the equilibrium state are usually non - gaussian . here , we study a system in which particles are allowed to move freely in a we present numerical simulations of a simple model of fluidized beds . in this model ,<n> hydrodynamic interaction among particles through the fluid is considered under the stokes approximation where the viscous effect of the fluid dominates the inertia of particles .<n> it is assumed that the impulse from the fluid , @xmath0 , is proportional to the velocity of the particles , _<n> i.e. _ the contact force . for the case of small flow rate of fluid<n> , particles rest in the _ fixed phase_. above the critical flow rate for the transition to the fluidized phase , the particles move _ in a bubbling phase _ , where the velocity distribution of particles changes from being non - gaussian to being gauss - like . to understand this behavior , we use the hole theory which has been used for simple liquids . we find that the effective viscosity , which is defined by the ratio of the friction coefficient to the effective temperature , depends on the flow - rate dependence of fluid . <n> pacs number(s ) : 05.20.-y , 05.40.-a , 47.54.+r in recent years  we present a model for the dynamics of fluidized beds .<n> the model is based on the concept of the effective stokes number @xmath0 , which is the average of the stokes numbers of the mobile and fixed particles in the fluidized bed . for the mobile particles<n> , we obtain the well - known effective stoke s number which is proportional to the force acting on the fixed particles . in the presence of the gravity , however , the model has a singularity at the contact point , where the fluidizes bed behaves as a fluid . <n> recently , there has been a lot of interest in the behavior of fluids in beds @xcite . from the theoretical point of view ,<n> the most interesting situation is that of a fluid in a bed , because the fluid is supposed to be the same as the gas in a solid . on the other hand , from the experimental point of views , it is very difficult to achieve the equilibrium between the two fluids because of the singularity of the lubrication . as a result of this difficulty<n> the equilibrium behavior of the system has not been investigated very well . here<n> we propose a model which can describe the equilibrium and nonequilibrium behavior of

samples.source_preview:
romanowsky et al . ( 2003 ) have recently presented dynamical studies of three elliptical galaxies based on the measurement of radial velocities of a large number of planetary nebulae in each of these galaxies . 
 this method is rather more reliable , and is extended to considerably larger radii , than the standard method of interpreting the line - of - sight - integrated line profiles ( see e.g. , gerhard et al . 
 2001 , and baes and dejonghe 2002 ) . 
 the dynamical modelling of romanowsky et
samples.reference: the recent findings of romanowsky et al . , of an `` unexpectedly '' small mass discrepancy within 5 effective radii in several elliptical galaxies , are not surprising in the context of mond . as we show here , they are , in fact , in full concordance with its predictions . one is dealing with high - surface - density galaxies with mean accelerations rather larger than the acceleration constant of mond . these findings continue , and are now the extreme examples of , the trend predicted by mond : the mass discrepancy sets in at larger and larger scaled radii in galaxies with larger and larger mean surface densities ; or , equivalently , mean accelerations .
samples.generated: we point out that the results of romanowsky et al . <n> ( 2003 ) , based on the study of planetary nebulae kinematics in three elliptical galaxies , go beyond existing support for mond , and probe , as they do , the highest acceleration end in the galaxy sequence , higher than what has been probed with rotation curves of spiral galaxies . we show that the mond predictions of the kinematics of galaxies studied by romanowsky et al . , as deduced from the observed light distribution assuming a constant @xmath0 value , agree well with the observations , assuming reasonable orbit populations .<n> this confirms the prediction of mond regarding the high acceleration end of the galaxy distribution , which has not been probed before . for ngc 3379 ,<n> the best studied galaxy , they deduce a rotation curve that becomes flat at about @math1 , in contrast to the flat rotation curves predicted by mond . we see , however , that , within the uncertainties due to measurement errors , modelling of the velocity data of the three galaxies , _ considering only models with a constant anisotropy ratio _ , leads to a mild mass discrepancy at the larger radii , where the data are more accurate , and where the uncertainty in orbit population is hardly present . in particular , we see that mond predicts the very pronounced decline in the deduced rotation curve of ngcs 3379 and 4494 , ( as never seen before ) . the main point is that this new comparison confirms the predictions of  gerhard et al . ( 2002 ) have recently presented measurements of the circular velocities of a sample of elliptical galaxies .<n> they claim that elliptical galaxies begin to deviate from a circular velocity law similar to that of spiral galaxies at radii smaller than @xmath0 , and that this onset of the mass discrepancy is accompanied by an increase in the circular velocity accelerations of ellipticals by an order of magnitude or more . here , we show that this claim is incorrect . <n> [ firstpage ] galaxies : elliptical and lenticular , cd ; quasars : general ; galaxy formation and evolution , observational cosmology . in their recent paper , gerhard , mclaughlin , & kjrgard ( 2002a ) ( hereafter mond ) , claimed that , in order to fit the observed radial velocity dispersion profiles of early - type galaxies ( edgs ) with a single , universal profile , one must assume that the velocity dispersion of the stellar component increases with radius @xcite . as a result ,<n> mond claimed that ellipticals deviate from the mond prediction in a manner that is similar to what is observed in spiral galaxies @x

samples.source_preview:
the bcs theory is considered as a conventional theory of superconductivity at a microscopic level , where bosonic excitations like phonons or spin fluctuations play the role of mediators in the formation of cooper pairs and hence superconductivity occurs in a metallic state . in recent years many varieties of superconductors have been discovered which are unconventional . 
 some examples are    1 . 
 cuprates , where anisotropic d - wave gaps occur with nodes ( vanishing gap ) at some symmetry p
samples.reference: the recently discovered multiband superconductors have created a new class of novel superconductors . in these materials multiple superconducting gaps arise due to the formation of cooper pairs on different sheets of the fermi surfaces . an important feature of these superconductors is the interband couplings , which not only change the individual gap properties , but also create new collective modes . here we investigate the effect of the interband couplings in the ginzburg - landau theory . we produce a general @xmath0 expansion ( @xmath1 ) and show that this expansion has unexpected behaviour for @xmath2 . this point emphasises the weaker validity of the gl theory for lower temperatures and gives credence to the existence of hidden criticality near the critical temperature of the uncoupled subdominant band .

band systems<n> we find that the gl expansion breaks down at @xmath0 , which is lower than the critical temperature for the single - band bcs theory . at higher temperatures additional terms in the expansion<n> are found to improve the agreement with the bcs results , especially for the multiband case . <n> # 1@xmath1#1 2 we present a self - based superconductors @xcite , in particular in the cuprates , due to their anomalous low - temperature resistivity , which can be explained as a consequence of the proximity - induced superfluidity in these materials . to date , most experimental studies of the superconductor - insulator transition have focused on the normal state , but a number of intriguing phenomena have been observed in the superconducting state . for example , it has been observed that the critical temperature of the uncoupled first band decreases with increasing doping , consistent with a scenario in which the cooper pairs form cooper pairs due to the coulomb interaction . also , the temperature dependence of the critical current has been measured in several experiments we compute the ginzburg - dimensional superconductor ( 1ds ) , while for a large correlation length it is different from a 1d bcs 1d superconductor such as the cuprate superconductors . <n> recently , there has been renewed interest in the problem of superconductivity in two dimensions ( 2d ) @xcite , driven by the discovery of the high temperature superconductor cuprates , which exhibit a variety of unusual physical properties , such as high critical temperatures , non - fermi liquid behavior , and the existence of majorana fermions . to understand the physics of these materials , we show that the gorkov approximation to the ginzburg - landau ( gl ) theory of one - band superconductors is only valid in a very small temperature range near the critical temperature @xmath0 , where the gl gaps are close to degenerate .<n> however , when the interband coupling is increased , the range of validity of the gl approximation increases significantly , and we find that the bcs result is not valid in this temperature range . in the case of two bands , we show how higher order corrections can be included to improve the agreement with the gl results . <n> recently , there has been renewed interest in the problem of two -  there have been numerous efforts to understand the phase structure of qcd at zero and finite temperature or density regions  @xcite . 
 chiral phase transition is detected by monitoring the order parameter , chiral condensate @xmath2 , whereas a polyakov loop is widely used in order to know whether a system is in the confinement phase or not .

samples.source_preview:
given the increasing age of many industrial systems and the dynamic industrial manufacturing market , intelligent and low - cost industrial automation systems are required to improve the productivity and efficiency of such systems [ 1 ] . 
 the collaborative nature of industrial wireless sensor networks ( iwsns ) brings several advantages over traditional wired industrial monitoring and control systems , including self - organization , rapid deployment , flexibility , and inherent intelligent -
samples.reference: with the development of wireless communication , industrial wireless sensor networks ( iwsns ) plays an important role in monitoring and control systems . in this paper , we extend the application of iwsns into high frequency surface - wave radar ( hfswr ) system . the traditional antenna is replaced by mobile iwsns . in combination of the application precondition of super - directivity in hf band and circular topology of iwsns , a super - directivity synthesis method is presented for designing super - directivity array . in this method , the dominance of external noise is ensured by constraining the ratio of external to internal noise ( rein ) of the array , and the desired side lobe level is achieved by implementing linear constraint . by using this method , the highest directivity will be achieved in certain conditions . using the designed super directive circular array as sub - arrays , the compact receive antenna array is constructed , the purpose of miniaturization is achieved . simulation verifies that the proposed method is correct and effective , the validity of the proposed method has been proved .
samples.generated: in this paper , super directive circular array is designed and compared by using industrial wireless sensor networks ( iwsns ) .<n> the highest directivity with certain constrains is achieved , and the size of the received antenna array is reduced . computer simulation verifies the correctness and affectivity of the proposed method . for high frequency surface - wave radar ( hfswr )<n> , the elements , which can monitor enemy aircrafts and missiles , are usually deployed near the coastline . in order to monitor enemy air targets , deployment regions of mwsns are vitally important to protect the military base . and<n> because the array size is very large , it is required that the array has super directivity . in this paper , we present a super - directivity synthesis method for designing array pattern with high directivity and small size .<n> the array is constructed by using 8 super directive circular arrays of sub - mwsns as sub - arrays and placed with a distance of 15__m__. the maximum directivity is achieved with sidelobe constrained under -25__db _ _ and rein satisfies the dominance of external noise condition . by optimizing array directivity subject to rein and sidelo be constraints , the maximum possible directivity can be achieved . the optimized array of super - directive circular with odd number of elements<n> may have a smaller size with the same directivity compared with conventional array . <n> the super -directivity synthesis ( sif ) method has been widely used for designing arrays pattern with optimal directivity , low power consumption , small size and low cost . in this work ,<n> we propose a method to design super - directed circular array with high and low directivity with the help of the lcmv ( linear combination of circular harmonics ) criterion , which is one of the most powerful criteria to design an array pattern , especially when the directivity of an array is in this paper , we propose a new method to design an antenna array with minimum mean squared error ( mmse ) .<n> the proposed method is based on the concept of local minimax optimization , which can be considered as an extension of the well - known minimax algorithm . in the minimax approach ,<n> the array is designed by minimizing the sum - of - squares ( s.s . )<n> error between the input and the output of the array , while minimizing the mean square error ( mss ) between the array and the input . as a result , the error of the designed array is lower than that of the input array . to demonstrate the effectiveness of the method , some numerical examples<n> are presented to show how the proposed approach can be used to design radio - frequency ( rf ) antenna arrays with mmse performance exceeding the theoretical bound , as well as to design rf antennas with the same mmse error as the input ones<n> . rf antenna , mmse estimation , pattern synthesis , minimax , error estimation .

samples.source_preview:
microparticle adhesion is central to fundamental areas such as surface science @xcite , geological material mechanics @xcite , granular media dynamics @xcite , and even planet formation @xcite . 
 improved understanding of microparticle adhesion has implications for applied areas including self - assembly @xcite , laser cleaning of semiconductors @xcite , powder processing @xcite , and drug delivery @xcite . 
 one method to study microparticle adhesion is to use laser - generated acoustic waves
samples.reference: the detachment of a semi - ordered monolayer of polystyrene microspheres adhered to an aluminum - coated glass substrate is studied using a laser - induced spallation technique . the microsphere - substrate adhesion force is estimated from substrate surface displacement measurements obtained using optical interferometry , and a rigid - body model that accounts for the inertia of the microspheres . the estimated adhesion force is compared with estimates obtained from interferometric measurement of the out - of - plane microsphere contact resonance . reasonable agreement is found between the two experiments . scanning electron microscope images of detached monolayer regions reveal a unique morphology , namely , partially detached monolayer flakes composed of single hexagonal close packed crystalline domains . this work contributes to an improved understanding of microsphere adhesion and demonstrates a unique monolayer delamination morphology .
samples.generated: we study the adhesion of a semi - ordered polystyrene ( ps ) microsphere monolayer to an aluminum - coated glass substrate , using a laser - induced spallation technique . the particle - substrate adhesive force is estimated by monitoring the time - resolved displacements of the surface of the substrate without the monolayer via optical inteferometry , and applying a rigid - body model that accounts for the microsphere inertia . we compare the estimated adhesive force with estimations based on measurements of the out - of - plane contact resonance of the ps microspheres .<n> we find that the force acting on the substrate is proportional to the square root of the particle size , @xmath0 , which is in agreement with the theoretical prediction for a rigid body model , but is significantly smaller than the estimated force based on the contact resonance measurements . in the case of delaminated monolayer areas ,<n> we observe a unique morphology wherein the mono layer has fractured into flakes that have partially reattached to the substrate and are composed of mostly single crystalline domains . laser - induced spallation is a common technique used to remove microspheres from patterned substrates . in this technique ,<n> a laser beam is used to excite the motion of a microsphere monolayer , which is subsequently laser - heated to produce a monolayer of laser - generated vortices .<n> we use this technique to study the adhesion , contact mechanics , and delamination of the monolayer as a function of the pump energy . at a pump energy of @xmath0 mj , we find that the adhesion force between the microsphere and the substrate is comparable to that obtained using a van der waals contact model , while the contact stiffness is smaller than predicted by the model . using the derjaguin - muller - toporov model for adhered microparticles and the dmt model for the adhesive force , the work of adhesion estimated from the laser induced spalation experiments<n> is found to be @xcite . <n> laser - driven spallations of patterned substrates have been used for decades as a method to remove micrometer - sized objects from surfaces , such as foils , plates , membranes , or porous media . for example , laser - laser - induced spallation of microsphere monolayers provides an opportunity to study the adhesion , contact mechanics , and fracture mechanics of three - dimensional microscale granular crystals . in this work ,<n> we study the microsphere - monolayer system generated by a femtosecond laser pulse with a peak intensity of @xmath0 mw@xmath1 .<n> the laser generates a spalled monolayer of micrometer - sized ps microspheres adhered to an air - water interface . by measuring the attenuation of the laser - generated spallations , we determine the microparticle adhesion force , which is in agreement with the predictions of the elastic contact model . finally , by comparing the measured data to the contact radius predicted by the vogel - fulcher - teukolsky ( dmt ) contact model and the work of mikhalevich and maznev ( phys . rev . <n> lett . * 102 * , 056401 , 2009 ) , the shear strength of the adhered monolayer is found to be larger than the predicted value , indicating that the adhesion of the monolayer may not be as strong as predicted by dm

samples.source_preview:
in the risk minimisation of portfolio optimisation it is very important to consider how the returns of different companies correlate with each other . for this purpose 
 the study of the equal time cross correlations between stocks has attracted much interest  @xcite : the clustering properties and the comparison between the time and ensemble averages have provided much useful information in this respect .    in statistical physics _ 
 time dependent _ correlations are also of major interest . d
samples.reference: we study the time dependent cross correlations of stock returns , i.e. we measure the correlation as the function of the time shift between pairs of stock return time series using tick - by - tick data . we find a weak but significant effect showing that in many cases the maximum correlation appears at nonzero time shift indicating directions of influence between the companies . due to the weakness of this effect and the shortness of the characteristic time ( of the order of a few minutes ) our findings are compatible with market efficiency . the interaction of companies defines a directed network of influence .
samples.generated: we study time - dependent cross - correlations between the returns of different stocks taken from the new york stock exchange .<n> it is shown that there exists some  pulling '' effect between the companies , _<n> i.e. _ , one of them influences the price behaviour of the others . however , this effect can not be strong and the shift should be small , otherwise the effect could be utilized for arbitrage purposes , which is excluded from an efficient market . we have analyzed the cross correlation functions of the returns of 195 companies at the nyse .<n> we have found that there exists a pulling effect , _<n> i.e. _ the influence of one stock on that of the other , which has been the main focus of our study in this article . in general<n> we can see two types of mechanisms to generate significant correlation between two stocks : a ) some external effect ( e.g. economic , political news etc . ) that influences both stock prices simultaneously ; b ) one of the stocks has an influence on the other ( _ i _ , in this case the influence depends on the less frequently traded one ) . as the correlation function of the original data sets decays exponentially , the position of the maximum of the correlation is at zero time shift . however , increasing the time difference , @xmath0 , we find that the maximum is shifted to a larger value and the decay of the correlations is approximately linearly , down to the noise level . we have also studied the shifted time correlation function for the first and second half of the given 3 month period and found that it is also linearly down we have analyzed the time - dependent cross correlation functions of the returns of stocks at the nyse .<n> we have found two types of mechanisms to generate significant correlation between two stocks : * some external effect ( e.g. economic , political news etc . ) that influences both stock prices simultaneously . in this case<n> the change for both prices appears at the same time , the maximum of the correlation is at zero time shift . * one of the companies has an influence to the other ( i.e. one ofthe companies pulls the other ) . this pulling effect has been the main focus of our study in this article . as for the pulling effect we found that generically the more traded , and thus more important companies pull the smaller ones . [ [ section ] ] the efficient market hypothesis ( emh ) assumes that the price of a stock is correlated with its value at a certain time . from this hypothesis<n> one can derive a number of useful results , for example the correlation between the price and the volume of traded shares , or the price - volume correlation function . however , most of these results rely on the assumption that the time dependence of the return auto - correlations in the field of oil and gas drilling , there are a number of challenges that need to be addressed before the field can be productive . among these challenges ,<n> one of the most important is the difficulty in extracting the energy from the well , which is usually accompanied by a considerable amount of pollution , noise , and man - made noise . in this paper , we present a study of the impact of noise and pollution on the efficiency of the well - performed functions .<n> the study is carried out by considering various noise sources in the environment , such as seismic waves , particle and nuclear particle noises , as well as electromagnetic and ultraviolet radiations . <n> the analysis is performed by using information - theoretic tools such as the generalized uncertainty principle , shannon entropy , the generalized casimir force and the casimir uncertainty relation . from the analysis of these noise sources<n> , it is found that the noise efficiency of a well is related to the total energy that can be extracted by the well and that the computer used to perform the well must be able to tolerate high noise levels . as a result , high efficiency is achieved when the computer is used in conjunction with a noiseless environment .

samples.reference: the ground state of hemispherical permalloy magnetic shell is studied . there exist two magnetic phases : the onion state and the vortex one . the phase diagram is systematically analyzed in a wide range of geometrical parameters . possible transitions between different phases are analyzed using the combination of analytical calculations and micromagnetic simulations . 2

which the magnetostatic energy of the spherical surface is replaced by its local counterpart , the easy surface anisotropy . using this approach<n> we calculate the phase diagram of the magnetization states in the most general case , i.e.  we present a detailed study of the ground state of hemispherical magnetic nanoshells , including monodomain ( onion ) state and the vortex one .<n> we propose a samples.source_preview:
the process of backscattering and fluorescence of x - rays from cosmic matter known as x - ray reflection is commonly observed throughout astronomy . 
 we are concerned here with the situation where the x - ray irradiation is so intense that it determines the ionization state of the material . 
 this occurs in accreting x - ray sources such as galactic black hole candidates ( bhc ) and active galactic nuclei ( agn ) , and may also be relevant to gamma - ray bursts ( grb ) . 
 the irradiated gas
samples.reference: x - ray ionized reflection occurs when a surface is irradiated with x - rays so intense that its ionization state is determined by the ionization parameter @xmath0 , where @xmath1 is the incident flux and @xmath2 the gas density . it occurs in accretion , onto compact objects including black holes in both active galaxies and stellar - mass binaries , and possibly in gamma - ray bursts . computation of model reflection spectra is often time - consuming . here we present the results from a comprehensive grid of models computed with our code , which has now been extended to include what we consider to be all energetically - important ionization states and transitions . this grid is being made available as an ionized - reflection model , reflion , for xspec . [ firstpage ] x - rays : general accretion , accretion discs galaxies : active radiative transfer line : formation
samples.generated: we present a grid of models for compton - scattered x - ray spectra from accretion discs around agn , bhc and grb .<n> the calculations are based on a non - lte fokker - planck / diffusion formalism , and include calculations of all abundant species and their important transitions . <n> the grids cover a wide range of photon energies ( @xmath0 kev ) and ionization states ( c , n , o , ne , mg , si , s , ar , fe , ni , zn ) , as well as a broad range of accretion rates ( 10@xmath1 solar masses per year at a distance of 1 kpc )<n> . the ionization parameter , the photon index of the illuminating radiation and the iron abundance are free parameters , so that the calculations can be used as a guide to the interpretation of agn and bhc spectra in general , or grb spectra in particular . in the latter case<n> , we find that the spectral shape can be strongly affected by the accretion rate , but that this has little effect on the ionization state of the illuminated gas , since the radiative and dielectronic recombination rates are calculated for a range of metallicities and thomson depths using the fits of arnaud & rothenflug ( 1985 ) and verner & ferland ( 1996 ) . at low metallicities , @xmath0 ,<n> the dielectronic rate is reduced by collisional ionization of resonance lines , while at high metallicities it is enhanced by the escape probability from resonance trapping .<n> the results are in reasonable agreement with the results of morrison & mccammon ( 1983 ) for low metallicity systems , but differ from those of dumont et al . <n> ( 2003 ) at higher metallicity . in the low - metallicity regime , recombination due to resonance - line photons<n> is found to dominate over that due to reemission in the far line wings , leading to an overall increase in the recombination rate by about a factor of two over the rate calculated using the milne relation . for metallicities<n> = [ z / h]@xmath1 , the dielectron recombination rate is found at a level of about 1 per cent of the total recombination rate , which is much lower than is found in the solar neighborhood we present a new method for calculating x - ray spectra from optically - thick metals .<n> the method is based on a monte - carlo simulation of compton scattering of resonance - line photons from the underlying continuum , and it accounts for all commonly important ionization states and transitions . as an application<n> , we calculate reflected spectra from metals with solar abundances . <n> [ [ section ] ] the optical properties of metals are determined by the ionization structure of the gas . in the limit of an infinite solid angle ,<n> the metal abundance is given by the formula @xmath0 , where the constant in the formula is equal to the logarithm of the thomson depth divided by the solar value . for metals with a solid angle of less than about 30@xmath1 , this formula<n> is known as the  universal abundance formula '' ( wefc ) @xcite , because it takes into account the contribution of each element to the ionization balance in the gas as if it were a free parameter . however , as is well - known , there are many nonuniversal elements in the universe , including oxygen , neon , magnesium , silicon , sulfur , iron x - ray spectra of active galactic nuclei ( agn ) from _ chandra _ and _ xmm - newton _ have been interpreted in terms of ionized reflection from the accretion disc .<n> however , such spectra are difficult to interpret in the x - rays of low - redshift quasars , where the accretion rate is very low . here<n> we show that a significant fraction of the incident x - radiation emerges as soft excess emission due to lines and bremsstrahlung from the hot surface layers , and we calculate reflection spectra from a disc with emissivity index 3 extending from 3 to 100 gravitational radii around a maximal kerr black hole , viewed at an inclination angle of 30 deg . <n> [ firstpage ] accretion , accretion discs black hole physics galaxies : active x - - rays : galaxies . we present a new method to determine the ionization structure of a photoionized plasma .<n> the method is based on the assumption that the plasma is isothermal and that the electron density is constant throughout the process . by comparing the results of this method with those of the monte carlo method ,<n> we show that the ionization parameter of the plasma can be determined with an accuracy of better than a factor of two . <n> [ firstpage ] atomic processes in the interstellar medium ( ism ) have been the focus of intense research efforts in recent years . in particular , it has been realized that the ism contains a large number of ionized species such as hydrogen , helium , carbon , nitrogen , oxygen , and sulfur , which have been detected in abundances in the range @xmath0 @xcite . as a result<n> , there has been a great deal of interest in the study of these species in the context of galaxy formation and evolution , supernovae , active galactic nuclei ( agn ) , as well as in studies of the chemical composition and the abundances of the various elements in the galaxy and in the local supercluster . to a large

 neglecting pomeron loops and choosing the projectile to have a short range and the target to be a heavy nucleus one comes to the well - known balitski - kovchegov ( bk ) equation , which sum
samples.reference: hadron - nucleus amplitudes at high energies are studied in the `` toy '' regge model in zero transverse dimension for finite nuclei , when the standard series of fan diagrams is converted into a finite sum and looses physical sense at quite low energies . taking into account all the loop contributions by numerical methods we find a physically meaningful amplitudes at all energies . they practically coincide with the amplitudes for infinite nuclei . a surprizing result is that for finite nuclei and small enough triple pomeron coupling the infinite series of fan diagrams describes the amplitude quite well in spite of the fact that in reality the series should be cut and as such deprived of any physical sense at high energies .

gribov theory of a pomeron field depending only on rapidity .<n> the amplitude depends on two variables : the scaled rapidity and the triple pomeron coupling constant . in the case of nucleus - nucleus scattering<n> the evolution of the amplitude is governed by two parameters , the ratio of the pomeron intercept to the rapidity at the scattering , and the coupling constants . <n> the values of these parameters are determined by a combination of two rules : ( i ) for the case when the couplings are the same we take the final state to be a single pomeron ; ( ii ) if the scattering state is different from the initial state we choose the initial one to be the same one . for the scattering of two nuclei we choose an initial state which is the same as the one used in the optical approximation ( ol ) , which is a mixture of excited states and excited states with the same quantum numbers . the amplitude evolves by means of a quasi - schroedinger equation ( qse ) which allows to solve the differential equation in the domain of rapidity we study the dependence of the ha amplitude on the scaled rapidity @xmath0 and on the values of the triple pomeron coupling in the case of nucleus - nucleus scattering .<n> it is shown that for nuclei with finite atomic numbers the amplitude is very weakly dependent on the value of the coupling and the rapidity at large rapidities . for finite nuclei<n> the dependence is much stronger and the amplitude becomes very close to the result for infinite nuclei . <n> the results of our calculations are in good agreement with the available data for the rapidities and values of couplings @xcite-@xcite . in the present paper<n> we study in more detail the dependence on rapidity of the amplitude for the scattering of a soft pomeron from a finite nucleus . here<n> we concentrate on the case when the initial pomeron state is chosen to be a single pomeron , that is f_0(u)=1-(1-u)a , f_f(u ) . the pomeron amplitude is calculated in the standard eikonal formalism , where the initial state is taken to be the finite nucleus and the final state is the proton . to pass to finite nuclei we change to the standard gla we study the hadron cross - section in high - energy hadron - hadron collisions ( ha ) in the framework of the pertubative qcd .<n> it is shown that the amplitude with contributions from loops for finite nuclei is in agreement with the amplitude obtained with the help of the standard infinite series of fan diagrams for the given atomic nucleus . at large energies<n> the amplitude is found to be independent on the initial amplitude and strongly dependent on the triple pomeron coupling @xmath0 , so that it can not be described by the standard fan diagrams . for realisitic nuclei with finite atomic numbers<n> the inclusion of the loop diagrams leads to a much better description of the ha amplitude . in spite of the fact that with a finite nucleus infinite fans<n> have nothing to do with the physical amplitude , the analytic continuation involved in extending the validity of the finite fans to infinite ones seems to take into account contributions from loop diagrams at small enough values of the pomeron interaction . this conclusion could explain the success of using infinite fan diagrams in the description of ha amplitudes both in the local regge theory and the perturbative quantum chromodynamics ( bk ) . <n> = 10000 high energy ( he ) hadron

samples.reference: i report on a sample of new type i x - ray bursters , firstly detected with the wide field cameras on board _ bepposax _ and then studied with the narrow field instruments on a broad spectral range ( 0.1 - 200 kev ) . properties of the transient / persistent emission are summarized and the broad band x - ray spectra discussed in detail for a few sources . _ istituto di astrofisica spaziale ( ias / cnr ) , via fosso del cavaliere 100,00133 roma , italy _ on behalf of the _ bepposax_/wfc galactic bulge collaboration
